text: When King David was very old, he could not keep warm even when they put covers over him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So his attendants said to him, ‘Let us look for a young virgin to serve the king and take care of him. She can lie beside him so that our lord the king may keep warm.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they searched throughout Israel for a beautiful young woman and found Abishag, a Shunammite, and brought her to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman was very beautiful; she took care of the king and waited on him, but the king had no sexual relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Adonijah, whose mother was Haggith, put himself forward and said, ‘I will be king.’ So he got chariots and horses ready, with fifty men to run ahead of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: (His father had never rebuked him by asking, ‘Why do you behave as you do?’ He was also very handsome and was born next after Absalom.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah conferred with Joab son of Zeruiah and with Abiathar the priest, and they gave him their support.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Zadok the priest, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei and Rei and David’s special guard did not join Adonijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah then sacrificed sheep, cattle and fattened calves at the Stone of Zoheleth near En Rogel. He invited all his brothers, the king’s sons, and all the royal officials of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he did not invite Nathan the prophet or Benaiah or the special guard or his brother Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Nathan asked Bathsheba, Solomon’s mother, ‘Have you not heard that Adonijah, the son of Haggith, has become king, and our lord David knows nothing about it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, let me advise you how you can save your own life and the life of your son Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go in to King David and say to him, “My lord the king, did you not swear to me your servant: ‘Surely Solomon your son shall be king after me, and he will sit on my throne’? Why then has Adonijah become king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: While you are still there talking to the king, I will come in and add my word to what you have said.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Bathsheba went to see the aged king in his room, where Abishag the Shunammite was attending him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bathsheba bowed down, prostrating herself before the king.
‘What is it you want?’ the king asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to him, ‘My lord, you yourself swore to me your servant by the Lord your God: “Solomon your son shall become king after me, and he will sit on my throne.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But now Adonijah has become king, and you, my lord the king, do not know about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has sacrificed great numbers of cattle, fattened calves, and sheep, and has invited all the king’s sons, Abiathar the priest and Joab the commander of the army, but he has not invited Solomon your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: My lord the king, the eyes of all Israel are on you, to learn from you who will sit on the throne of my lord the king after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, as soon as my lord the king is laid to rest with his ancestors, I and my son Solomon will be treated as criminals.’
speaker: Narrator

text: While she was still speaking with the king, Nathan the prophet arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king was told, ‘Nathan the prophet is here.’ So he went before the king and bowed with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan said, ‘Have you, my lord the king, declared that Adonijah shall be king after you, and that he will sit on your throne?
speaker: Narrator

text: Today he has gone down and sacrificed great numbers of cattle, fattened calves, and sheep. He has invited all the king’s sons, the commanders of the army and Abiathar the priest. At this very moment they are eating and drinking with him and saying, “Long live King Adonijah!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But me your servant, and Zadok the priest, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and your servant Solomon he did not invite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is this something my lord the king has done without letting his servants know who should sit on the throne of my lord the king after him?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King David said, ‘Call in Bathsheba.’ So she came into the king’s presence and stood before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king then took an oath: ‘As surely as the Lord lives, who has delivered me out of every trouble,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will surely carry out this very day what I swore to you by the Lord, the God of Israel: Solomon your son shall be king after me, and he will sit on my throne in my place.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bathsheba bowed down with her face to the ground, prostrating herself before the king, and said, ‘May my lord King David live for ever!’
speaker: Narrator

text: King David said, ‘Call in Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet and Benaiah son of Jehoiada.’ When they came before the king,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said to them: ‘Take your lord’s servants with you and put Solomon my son on my own mule and take him down to Gihon.
speaker: Narrator

text: There shall Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anoint him king over Israel. Blow the trumpet and shout, “Long live King Solomon!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you are to go up with him, and he is to come and sit on my throne and reign in my place. I have appointed him ruler over Israel and Judah.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada answered the king, ‘Amen! May the Lord, the God of my lord the king, so declare it.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Lord was with my lord the king, so may he be with Solomon to make his throne even greater than the throne of my lord King David!’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, the Kerethites and the Pelethites went down and put Solomon on King David’s mule, and they escorted him to Gihon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zadok the priest took the horn of oil from the sacred tent and anointed Solomon. Then they sounded the trumpet and all the people shouted, ‘Long live King Solomon!’
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the people went up after him, playing pipes and rejoicing greatly, so that the ground shook with the sound.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah and all the guests who were with him heard it as they were finishing their feast. On hearing the sound of the trumpet, Joab asked, ‘What’s the meaning of all the noise in the city?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Even as he was speaking, Jonathan son of Abiathar the priest arrived. Adonijah said, ‘Come in. A worthy man like you must be bringing good news.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Not at all!’ Jonathan answered. ‘Our lord King David has made Solomon king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king has sent with him Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, the Kerethites and the Pelethites, and they have put him on the king’s mule,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet have anointed him king at Gihon. From there they have gone up cheering, and the city resounds with it. That’s the noise you hear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, Solomon has taken his seat on the royal throne.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, the royal officials have come to congratulate our lord King David, saying, “May your God make Solomon’s name more famous than yours and his throne greater than yours!” And the king bowed in worship on his bed
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “Praise be to the Lord, the God of Israel, who has allowed my eyes to see a successor on my throne today.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, all Adonijah’s guests rose in alarm and dispersed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Adonijah, in fear of Solomon, went and took hold of the horns of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon was told, ‘Adonijah is afraid of King Solomon and is clinging to the horns of the altar. He says, “Let King Solomon swear to me today that he will not put his servant to death with the sword.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon replied, ‘If he shows himself to be worthy, not a hair of his head will fall to the ground; but if evil is found in him, he will die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Solomon sent men, and they brought him down from the altar. And Adonijah came and bowed down to King Solomon, and Solomon said, ‘Go to your home.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time drew near for David to die, he gave a charge to Solomon his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I am about to go the way of all the earth,’ he said. ‘So be strong, act like a man,
speaker: Narrator

text: and observe what the Lord your God requires: walk in obedience to him, and keep his decrees and commands, his laws and regulations, as written in the Law of Moses. Do this so that you may prosper in all you do and wherever you go
speaker: Narrator

text: and that the Lord may keep his promise to me: “If your descendants watch how they live, and if they walk faithfully before me with all their heart and soul, you will never fail to have a successor on the throne of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now you yourself know what Joab son of Zeruiah did to me – what he did to the two commanders of Israel’s armies, Abner son of Ner and Amasa son of Jether. He killed them, shedding their blood in peacetime as if in battle, and with that blood he stained the belt round his waist and the sandals on his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Deal with him according to your wisdom, but do not let his grey head go down to the grave in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But show kindness to the sons of Barzillai of Gilead and let them be among those who eat at your table. They stood by me when I fled from your brother Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And remember, you have with you Shimei son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim, who called down bitter curses on me the day I went to Mahanaim. When he came down to meet me at the Jordan, I swore to him by the Lord: “I will not put you to death by the sword.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, do not consider him innocent. You are a man of wisdom; you will know what to do to him. Bring his grey head down to the grave in blood.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David rested with his ancestors and was buried in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had reigned for forty years over Israel – seven years in Hebron and thirty-three in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon sat on the throne of his father David, and his rule was firmly established.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now Adonijah, the son of Haggith, went to Bathsheba, Solomon’s mother. Bathsheba asked him, ‘Do you come peacefully?’
He answered, ‘Yes, peacefully.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he added, ‘I have something to say to you.’
‘You may say it,’ she replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘As you know,’ he said, ‘the kingdom was mine. All Israel looked to me as their king. But things changed, and the kingdom has gone to my brother; for it has come to him from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now I have one request to make of you. Do not refuse me.’
‘You may make it,’ she said.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he continued, ‘Please ask King Solomon – he will not refuse you – to give me Abishag the Shunammite as my wife.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Very well,’ Bathsheba replied, ‘I will speak to the king for you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Bathsheba went to King Solomon to speak to him for Adonijah, the king stood up to meet her, bowed down to her and sat down on his throne. He had a throne brought for the king’s mother, and she sat down at his right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I have one small request to make of you,’ she said. ‘Do not refuse me.’
The king replied, ‘Make it, my mother; I will not refuse you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So she said, ‘Let Abishag the Shunammite be given in marriage to your brother Adonijah.’
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon answered his mother, ‘Why do you request Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? You might as well request the kingdom for him – after all, he is my older brother – yes, for him and for Abiathar the priest and Joab son of Zeruiah!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Solomon swore by the Lord: ‘May God deal with me, be it ever so severely, if Adonijah does not pay with his life for this request!
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, as surely as the Lord lives – he who has established me securely on the throne of my father David and has founded a dynasty for me as he promised – Adonijah shall be put to death today!’
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Solomon gave orders to Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and he struck down Adonijah and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Abiathar the priest the king said, ‘Go back to your fields in Anathoth. You deserve to die, but I will not put you to death now, because you carried the ark of the Sovereign Lord before my father David and shared all my father’s hardships.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon removed Abiathar from the priesthood of the Lord, fulfilling the word the Lord had spoken at Shiloh about the house of Eli.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the news reached Joab, who had conspired with Adonijah though not with Absalom, he fled to the tent of the Lord and took hold of the horns of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon was told that Joab had fled to the tent of the Lord and was beside the altar. Then Solomon ordered Benaiah son of Jehoiada, ‘Go, strike him down!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Benaiah entered the tent of the Lord and said to Joab, ‘The king says, “Come out!”’
But he answered, ‘No, I will die here.’
Benaiah reported to the king, ‘This is how Joab answered me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king commanded Benaiah, ‘Do as he says. Strike him down and bury him, and so clear me and my whole family of the guilt of the innocent blood that Joab shed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will repay him for the blood he shed, because without my father David knowing it he attacked two men and killed them with the sword. Both of them – Abner son of Ner, commander of Israel’s army, and Amasa son of Jether, commander of Judah’s army – were better men and more upright than he.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the guilt of their blood rest on the head of Joab and his descendants for ever. But on David and his descendants, his house and his throne, may there be the Lord’s peace for ever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Benaiah son of Jehoiada went up and struck down Joab and killed him, and he was buried at his home out in the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king put Benaiah son of Jehoiada over the army in Joab’s position and replaced Abiathar with Zadok the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king sent for Shimei and said to him, ‘Build yourself a house in Jerusalem and live there, but do not go anywhere else.
speaker: Narrator

text: The day you leave and cross the Kidron Valley, you can be sure you will die; your blood will be on your own head.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei answered the king, ‘What you say is good. Your servant will do as my lord the king has said.’ And Shimei stayed in Jerusalem for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: But three years later, two of Shimei’s slaves ran off to Achish son of Maakah, king of Gath, and Shimei was told, ‘Your slaves are in Gath.’
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, he saddled his donkey and went to Achish at Gath in search of his slaves. So Shimei went away and brought the slaves back from Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Solomon was told that Shimei had gone from Jerusalem to Gath and had returned,
speaker: Narrator

text: the king summoned Shimei and said to him, ‘Did I not make you swear by the Lord and warn you, “On the day you leave to go anywhere else, you can be sure you will die”? At that time you said to me, “What you say is good. I will obey.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Why then did you not keep your oath to the Lord and obey the command I gave you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also said to Shimei, ‘You know in your heart all the wrong you did to my father David. Now the Lord will repay you for your wrongdoing.
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Solomon will be blessed, and David’s throne will remain secure before the Lord for ever.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king gave the order to Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and he went out and struck Shimei down and he died.
The kingdom was now established in Solomon’s hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon made an alliance with Pharaoh king of Egypt and married his daughter. He brought her to the City of David until he finished building his palace and the temple of the Lord, and the wall around Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people, however, were still sacrificing at the high places, because a temple had not yet been built for the Name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon showed his love for the Lord by walking according to the instructions given him by his father David, except that he offered sacrifices and burned incense on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king went to Gibeon to offer sacrifices, for that was the most important high place, and Solomon offered a thousand burnt offerings on that altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Gibeon the Lord appeared to Solomon during the night in a dream, and God said, ‘Ask for whatever you want me to give you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon answered, ‘You have shown great kindness to your servant, my father David, because he was faithful to you and righteous and upright in heart. You have continued this great kindness to him and have given him a son to sit on his throne this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now, Lord my God, you have made your servant king in place of my father David. But I am only a little child and do not know how to carry out my duties.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant is here among the people you have chosen, a great people, too numerous to count or number.
speaker: Narrator

text: So give your servant a discerning heart to govern your people and to distinguish between right and wrong. For who is able to govern this great people of yours?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was pleased that Solomon had asked for this.
speaker: Narrator

text: So God said to him, ‘Since you have asked for this and not for long life or wealth for yourself, nor have asked for the death of your enemies but for discernment in administering justice,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will do what you have asked. I will give you a wise and discerning heart, so that there will never have been anyone like you, nor will there ever be.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, I will give you what you have not asked for – both wealth and honour – so that in your lifetime you will have no equal among kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you walk in obedience to me and keep my decrees and commands as David your father did, I will give you a long life.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Solomon awoke – and he realised it had been a dream.
He returned to Jerusalem, stood before the ark of the Lord’s covenant and sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. Then he gave a feast for all his court.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now two prostitutes came to the king and stood before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them said, ‘Pardon me, my lord. This woman and I live in the same house. I had a baby while she was there with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third day after my child was born, this woman also had a baby. We were alone; there was no one in the house but the two of us.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘During the night this woman’s son died because she lay on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So she got up in the middle of the night and took my son from my side while I your servant was asleep. She put him by her breast and put her dead son by my breast.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning, I got up to nurse my son – and he was dead! But when I looked at him closely in the morning light, I saw that it wasn’t the son I had borne.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The other woman said, ‘No! The living one is my son; the dead one is yours.’
But the first one insisted, ‘No! The dead one is yours; the living one is mine.’ And so they argued before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, ‘This one says, “My son is alive and your son is dead,” while that one says, “No! Your son is dead and mine is alive.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said, ‘Bring me a sword.’ So they brought a sword for the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then gave an order: ‘Cut the living child in two and give half to one and half to the other.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The woman whose son was alive was deeply moved out of love for her son and said to the king, ‘Please, my lord, give her the living baby! Don’t kill him!’
But the other said, ‘Neither I nor you shall have him. Cut him in two!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king gave his ruling: ‘Give the living baby to the first woman. Do not kill him; she is his mother.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When all Israel heard the verdict the king had given, they held the king in awe, because they saw that he had wisdom from God to administer justice.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Solomon ruled over all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And these were his chief officials:
Azariah son of Zadok – the priest;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elihoreph and Ahijah, sons of Shisha – secretaries;
Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud – recorder;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Benaiah son of Jehoiada – commander-in-chief;
Zadok and Abiathar – priests;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Azariah son of Nathan – in charge of the district governors;
Zabud son of Nathan – a priest and advisor to the king;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahishar – palace administrator;
Adoniram son of Abda – in charge of forced labour.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon had twelve district governors over all Israel, who supplied provisions for the king and the royal household. Each one had to provide supplies for one month in the year.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are their names:
Ben-Hur – in the hill country of Ephraim;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-Deker – in Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth Shemesh and Elon Bethhanan;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-Hesed – in Arubboth (Sokoh and all the land of Hepher were his);
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-Abinadab – in Naphoth Dor (he was married to Taphath daughter of Solomon);
speaker: Narrator

text: Baana son of Ahilud – in Taanach and Megiddo, and in all of Beth Shan next to Zarethan below Jezreel, from Beth Shan to Abel Meholah across to Jokmeam;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-Geber – in Ramoth Gilead (the settlements of Jair son of Manasseh in Gilead were his, as well as the region of Argob in Bashan and its sixty large walled cities with bronze gate bars);
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahinadab son of Iddo – in Mahanaim;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahimaaz – in Naphtali (he had married Basemath daughter of Solomon);
speaker: Narrator

text: Baana son of Hushai – in Asher and in Aloth;
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat son of Paruah – in Issachar;
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei son of Ela – in Benjamin;
speaker: Narrator

text: Geber son of Uri – in Gilead (the country of Sihon king of the Amorites and the country of Og king of Bashan). He was the only governor over the district.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Judah and Israel were as numerous as the sand on the seashore; they ate, they drank and they were happy.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Solomon ruled over all the kingdoms from the River Euphrates to the land of the Philistines, as far as the border of Egypt. These countries brought tribute and were Solomon’s subjects all his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon’s daily provisions were thirty cors of the finest flour and sixty cors of meal,
speaker: Narrator

text: ten head of stall-fed cattle, twenty of pasture-fed cattle and a hundred sheep and goats, as well as deer, gazelles, roebucks and choice fowl.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he ruled over all the kingdoms west of the River Euphrates, from Tiphsah to Gaza, and had peace on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: During Solomon’s lifetime Judah and Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, lived in safety, everyone under their own vine and under their own fig-tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon had four thousand stalls for chariot horses, and twelve thousand horses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The district governors, each in his month, supplied provisions for King Solomon and all who came to the king’s table. They saw to it that nothing was lacking.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also brought to the proper place their quotas of barley and straw for the chariot horses and the other horses.
speaker: Narrator

text: God gave Solomon wisdom and very great insight, and a breadth of understanding as measureless as the sand on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon’s wisdom was greater than the wisdom of all the people of the East, and greater than all the wisdom of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was wiser than anyone else, including Ethan the Ezrahite – wiser than Heman, Kalkol and Darda, the sons of Mahol. And his fame spread to all the surrounding nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: He spoke three thousand proverbs and his songs numbered a thousand and five.
speaker: Narrator

text: He spoke about plant life, from the cedar of Lebanon to the hyssop that grows out of walls. He also spoke about animals and birds, reptiles and fish.
speaker: Narrator

text: From all nations people came to listen to Solomon’s wisdom, sent by all the kings of the world, who had heard of his wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hiram king of Tyre heard that Solomon had been anointed king to succeed his father David, he sent his envoys to Solomon, because he had always been on friendly terms with David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon sent back this message to Hiram:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You know that because of the wars waged against my father David from all sides, he could not build a temple for the Name of the Lord his God until the Lord put his enemies under his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now the Lord my God has given me rest on every side, and there is no adversary or disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: I intend, therefore, to build a temple for the Name of the Lord my God, as the Lord told my father David, when he said, “Your son whom I will put on the throne in your place will build the temple for my Name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘So give orders that cedars of Lebanon be cut for me. My men will work with yours, and I will pay you for your men whatever wages you set. You know that we have no one so skilled in felling timber as the Sidonians.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hiram heard Solomon’s message, he was greatly pleased and said, ‘Praise be to the Lord today, for he has given David a wise son to rule over this great nation.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Hiram sent word to Solomon:
‘I have received the message you sent me and will do all you want in providing the cedar and juniper logs.
speaker: Narrator

text: My men will haul them down from Lebanon to the Mediterranean Sea, and I will float them as rafts by sea to the place you specify. There I will separate them and you can take them away. And you are to grant my wish by providing food for my royal household.’
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way Hiram kept Solomon supplied with all the cedar and juniper logs he wanted,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Solomon gave Hiram twenty thousand cors of wheat as food for his household, in addition to twenty thousand baths of pressed olive oil. Solomon continued to do this for Hiram year after year.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord gave Solomon wisdom, just as he had promised him. There were peaceful relations between Hiram and Solomon, and the two of them made a treaty.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon conscripted labourers from all Israel – thirty thousand men.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent them off to Lebanon in shifts of ten thousand a month, so that they spent one month in Lebanon and two months at home. Adoniram was in charge of the forced labour.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon had seventy thousand carriers and eighty thousand stonecutters in the hills,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as thirty-three hundred foremen who supervised the project and directed the workers.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the king’s command they removed from the quarry large blocks of high-grade stone to provide a foundation of dressed stone for the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The craftsmen of Solomon and Hiram and workers from Byblos cut and prepared the timber and stone for the building of the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the four hundred and eightieth year after the Israelites came out of Egypt, in the fourth year of Solomon’s reign over Israel, in the month of Ziv, the second month, he began to build the temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The temple that King Solomon built for the Lord was sixty cubits long, twenty wide and thirty high.
speaker: Narrator

text: The portico at the front of the main hall of the temple extended the width of the temple, that is twenty cubits, and projected ten cubits from the front of the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made narrow windows high up in the temple walls.
speaker: Narrator

text: Against the walls of the main hall and inner sanctuary he built a structure around the building, in which there were side rooms.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lowest floor was five cubits wide, the middle floor six cubits and the third floor seven. He made offset ledges around the outside of the temple so that nothing would be inserted into the temple walls.
speaker: Narrator

text: In building the temple, only blocks dressed at the quarry were used, and no hammer, chisel or any other iron tool was heard at the temple site while it was being built.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entrance to the lowest floor was on the south side of the temple; a stairway led up to the middle level and from there to the third.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he built the temple and completed it, roofing it with beams and cedar planks.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he built the side rooms all along the temple. The height of each was five cubits, and they were attached to the temple by beams of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to Solomon:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘As for this temple you are building, if you follow my decrees, observe my laws and keep all my commands and obey them, I will fulfil through you the promise I gave to David your father.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will live among the Israelites and will not abandon my people Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon built the temple and completed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lined its interior walls with cedar boards, panelling them from the floor of the temple to the ceiling, and covered the floor of the temple with planks of juniper.
speaker: Narrator

text: He partitioned off twenty cubits at the rear of the temple with cedar boards from floor to ceiling to form within the temple an inner sanctuary, the Most Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The main hall in front of this room was forty cubits long.
speaker: Narrator

text: The inside of the temple was cedar, carved with gourds and open flowers. Everything was cedar; no stone was to be seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: He prepared the inner sanctuary within the temple to set the ark of the covenant of the Lord there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The inner sanctuary was twenty cubits long, twenty wide and twenty high. He overlaid the inside with pure gold, and he also overlaid the altar of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon covered the inside of the temple with pure gold, and he extended gold chains across the front of the inner sanctuary, which was overlaid with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he overlaid the whole interior with gold. He also overlaid with gold the altar that belonged to the inner sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the inner sanctuary he made a pair of cherubim out of olive wood, each ten cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: One wing of the first cherub was five cubits long, and the other wing five cubits – ten cubits from wing tip to wing tip.
speaker: Narrator

text: The second cherub also measured ten cubits, for the two cherubim were identical in size and shape.
speaker: Narrator

text: The height of each cherub was ten cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: He placed the cherubim inside the innermost room of the temple, with their wings spread out. The wing of one cherub touched one wall, while the wing of the other touched the other wall, and their wings touched each other in the middle of the room.
speaker: Narrator

text: He overlaid the cherubim with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the walls all round the temple, in both the inner and outer rooms, he carved cherubim, palm trees and open flowers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also covered the floors of both the inner and outer rooms of the temple with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the entrance to the inner sanctuary he made doors out of olive wood that were one fifth of the width of the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on the two olive-wood doors he carved cherubim, palm trees and open flowers, and overlaid the cherubim and palm trees with hammered gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, for the entrance to the main hall he made doorframes out of olive wood that were one quarter of the width of the hall.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made two doors out of juniper wood, each having two leaves that turned in sockets.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carved cherubim, palm trees and open flowers on them and overlaid them with gold hammered evenly over the carvings.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he built the inner courtyard of three courses of dressed stone and one course of trimmed cedar beams.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foundation of the temple of the Lord was laid in the fourth year, in the month of Ziv.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the eleventh year in the month of Bul, the eighth month, the temple was finished in all its details according to its specifications. He had spent seven years building it.
speaker: Narrator

text: It took Solomon thirteen years, however, to complete the construction of his palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon a hundred cubits long, fifty wide and thirty high, with four rows of cedar columns supporting trimmed cedar beams.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was roofed with cedar above the beams that rested on the columns – forty-five beams, fifteen to a row.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its windows were placed high in sets of three, facing each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the doorways had rectangular frames; they were in the front part in sets of three, facing each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made a colonnade fifty cubits long and thirty wide. In front of it was a portico, and in front of that were pillars and an overhanging roof.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built the throne hall, the Hall of Justice, where he was to judge, and he covered it with cedar from floor to ceiling.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the palace in which he was to live, set farther back, was similar in design. Solomon also made a palace like this hall for Pharaoh’s daughter, whom he had married.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these structures, from the outside to the great courtyard and from foundation to eaves, were made of blocks of high-grade stone cut to size and smoothed on their inner and outer faces.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foundations were laid with large stones of good quality, some measuring ten cubits and some eight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above were high-grade stones, cut to size, and cedar beams.
speaker: Narrator

text: The great courtyard was surrounded by a wall of three courses of dressed stone and one course of trimmed cedar beams, as was the inner courtyard of the temple of the Lord with its portico.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon sent to Tyre and brought Huram,
speaker: Narrator

text: whose mother was a widow from the tribe of Naphtali and whose father was from Tyre and a skilled craftsman in bronze. Huram was filled with wisdom, with understanding and with knowledge to do all kinds of bronze work. He came to King Solomon and did all the work assigned to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cast two bronze pillars, each eighteen cubits high and twelve cubits in circumference.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made two capitals of cast bronze to set on the tops of the pillars; each capital was five cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: A network of interwoven chains adorned the capitals on top of the pillars, seven for each capital.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made pomegranates in two rows encircling each network to decorate the capitals on top of the pillars. He did the same for each capital.
speaker: Narrator

text: The capitals on top of the pillars in the portico were in the shape of lilies, four cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the capitals of both pillars, above the bowl-shaped part next to the network, were the two hundred pomegranates in rows all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: He erected the pillars at the portico of the temple. The pillar to the south he named Jakin and the one to the north Boaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: The capitals on top were in the shape of lilies. And so the work on the pillars was completed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the Sea of cast metal, circular in shape, measuring ten cubits from rim to rim and five cubits high. It took a line of thirty cubits to measure round it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Below the rim, gourds encircled it – ten to a cubit. The gourds were cast in two rows in one piece with the Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Sea stood on twelve bulls, three facing north, three facing west, three facing south and three facing east. The Sea rested on top of them, and their hindquarters were towards the centre.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was a handbreadth in thickness, and its rim was like the rim of a cup, like a lily blossom. It held two thousand baths.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made ten movable stands of bronze; each was four cubits long, four wide and three high.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how the stands were made: they had side panels attached to uprights.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the panels between the uprights were lions, bulls and cherubim – and on the uprights as well. Above and below the lions and bulls were wreaths of hammered work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each stand had four bronze wheels with bronze axles, and each had a basin resting on four supports, cast with wreaths on each side.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the inside of the stand there was an opening that had a circular frame one cubit deep. This opening was round, and with its basework it measured a cubit and a half. Around its opening there was engraving. The panels of the stands were square, not round.
speaker: Narrator

text: The four wheels were under the panels, and the axles of the wheels were attached to the stand. The diameter of each wheel was a cubit and a half.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wheels were made like chariot wheels; the axles, rims, spokes and hubs were all of cast metal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each stand had four handles, one on each corner, projecting from the stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the top of the stand there was a circular band half a cubit deep. The supports and panels were attached to the top of the stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: He engraved cherubim, lions and palm trees on the surfaces of the supports and on the panels, in every available space, with wreaths all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the way he made the ten stands. They were all cast in the same moulds and were identical in size and shape.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then made ten bronze basins, each holding forty baths and measuring four cubits across, one basin to go on each of the ten stands.
speaker: Narrator

text: He placed five of the stands on the south side of the temple and five on the north. He placed the Sea on the south side, at the south-east corner of the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He also made the pots and shovels and sprinkling bowls.
So Huram finished all the work he had undertaken for King Solomon in the temple of the Lord:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: the four hundred pomegranates for the two sets of network (two rows of pomegranates for each network decorating the bowl-shaped capitals on top of the pillars);
speaker: Narrator

text: the ten stands with their ten basins;
speaker: Narrator

text: the Sea and the twelve bulls under it;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the pots, shovels and sprinkling bowls.
All these objects that Huram made for King Solomon for the temple of the Lord were of burnished bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king had them cast in clay moulds in the plain of the Jordan between Sukkoth and Zarethan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon left all these things unweighed, because there were so many; the weight of the bronze was not determined.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
the lampstands of pure gold (five on the right and five on the left, in front of the inner sanctuary);
the gold floral work and lamps and tongs;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the pure gold dishes, wick trimmers, sprinkling bowls, dishes and censers;
and the gold sockets for the doors of the innermost room, the Most Holy Place, and also for the doors of the main hall of the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the work King Solomon had done for the temple of the Lord was finished, he brought in the things his father David had dedicated – the silver and gold and the furnishings – and he placed them in the treasuries of the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Solomon summoned into his presence at Jerusalem the elders of Israel, all the heads of the tribes and the chiefs of the Israelite families, to bring up the ark of the Lord’s covenant from Zion, the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Israelites came together to King Solomon at the time of the festival in the month of Ethanim, the seventh month.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the elders of Israel had arrived, the priests took up the ark,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they brought up the ark of the Lord and the tent of meeting and all the sacred furnishings in it. The priests and Levites carried them up,
speaker: Narrator

text: and King Solomon and the entire assembly of Israel that had gathered about him were before the ark, sacrificing so many sheep and cattle that they could not be recorded or counted.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests then brought the ark of the Lord’s covenant to its place in the inner sanctuary of the temple, the Most Holy Place, and put it beneath the wings of the cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cherubim spread their wings over the place of the ark and overshadowed the ark and its carrying poles.
speaker: Narrator

text: These poles were so long that their ends could be seen from the Holy Place in front of the inner sanctuary, but not from outside the Holy Place; and they are still there today.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was nothing in the ark except the two stone tablets that Moses had placed in it at Horeb, where the Lord made a covenant with the Israelites after they came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the priests withdrew from the Holy Place, the cloud filled the temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the priests could not perform their service because of the cloud, for the glory of the Lord filled his temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon said, ‘The Lord has said that he would dwell in a dark cloud;
speaker: Narrator

text: I have indeed built a magnificent temple for you, a place for you to dwell for ever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: While the whole assembly of Israel was standing there, the king turned round and blessed them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said:
‘Praise be to the Lord, the God of Israel, who with his own hand has fulfilled what he promised with his own mouth to my father David. For he said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Since the day I brought my people Israel out of Egypt, I have not chosen a city in any tribe of Israel to have a temple built so that my Name might be there, but I have chosen David to rule my people Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘My father David had it in his heart to build a temple for the Name of the Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to my father David, “You did well to have it in your heart to build a temple for my Name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, you are not the one to build the temple, but your son, your own flesh and blood – he is the one who will build the temple for my Name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The Lord has kept the promise he made: I have succeeded David my father and now I sit on the throne of Israel, just as the Lord promised, and I have built the temple for the Name of the Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have provided a place there for the ark, in which is the covenant of the Lord that he made with our ancestors when he brought them out of Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon stood before the altar of the Lord in front of the whole assembly of Israel, spread out his hands towards heaven
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said:
‘Lord, the God of Israel, there is no God like you in heaven above or on earth below – you who keep your covenant of love with your servants who continue wholeheartedly in your way.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have kept your promise to your servant David my father; with your mouth you have promised and with your hand you have fulfilled it – as it is today.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now Lord, the God of Israel, keep for your servant David my father the promises you made to him when you said, “You shall never fail to have a successor to sit before me on the throne of Israel, if only your descendants are careful in all they do to walk before me faithfully as you have done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, God of Israel, let your word that you promised your servant David my father come true.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But will God really dwell on earth? The heavens, even the highest heaven, cannot contain you. How much less this temple I have built!
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet give attention to your servant’s prayer and his plea for mercy, Lord my God. Hear the cry and the prayer that your servant is praying in your presence this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: May your eyes be open towards this temple night and day, this place of which you said, “My Name shall be there,” so that you will hear the prayer your servant prays towards this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear the supplication of your servant and of your people Israel when they pray towards this place. Hear from heaven, your dwelling place, and when you hear, forgive.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When anyone wrongs their neighbour and is required to take an oath and they come and swear the oath before your altar in this temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear from heaven and act. Judge between your servants, condemning the guilty by bringing down on their heads what they have done, and vindicating the innocent by treating them in accordance with their innocence.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When your people Israel have been defeated by an enemy because they have sinned against you, and when they turn back to you and give praise to your name, praying and making supplication to you in this temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear from heaven and forgive the sin of your people Israel and bring them back to the land you gave to their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When the heavens are shut up and there is no rain because your people have sinned against you, and when they pray towards this place and give praise to your name and turn from their sin because you have afflicted them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear from heaven and forgive the sin of your servants, your people Israel. Teach them the right way to live, and send rain on the land you gave your people for an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When famine or plague comes to the land, or blight or mildew, locusts or grasshoppers, or when an enemy besieges them in any of their cities, whatever disaster or disease may come,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when a prayer or plea is made by anyone among your people Israel – being aware of the afflictions of their own hearts, and spreading out their hands towards this temple –
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear from heaven, your dwelling-place. Forgive and act; deal with everyone according to all they do, since you know their hearts (for you alone know every human heart),
speaker: Narrator

text: so that they will fear you all the time they live in the land you gave our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘As for the foreigner who does not belong to your people Israel but has come from a distant land because of your name –
speaker: Narrator

text: for they will hear of your great name and your mighty hand and your outstretched arm – when they come and pray towards this temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear from heaven, your dwelling-place. Do whatever the foreigner asks of you, so that all the peoples of the earth may know your name and fear you, as do your own people Israel, and may know that this house I have built bears your Name.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When your people go to war against their enemies, wherever you send them, and when they pray to the Lord towards the city you have chosen and the temple I have built for your Name,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear from heaven their prayer and their plea, and uphold their cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When they sin against you – for there is no one who does not sin – and you become angry with them and give them over to their enemies, who take them captive to their own lands, far away or near;
speaker: Narrator

text: and if they have a change of heart in the land where they are held captive, and repent and plead with you in the land of their captors and say, “We have sinned, we have done wrong, we have acted wickedly”;
speaker: Narrator

text: and if they turn back to you with all their heart and soul in the land of their enemies who took them captive, and pray to you towards the land you gave their ancestors, towards the city you have chosen and the temple I have built for your Name;
speaker: Narrator

text: then from heaven, your dwelling-place, hear their prayer and their plea, and uphold their cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: And forgive your people, who have sinned against you; forgive all the offences they have committed against you, and cause their captors to show them mercy;
speaker: Narrator

text: for they are your people and your inheritance, whom you brought out of Egypt, out of that iron-smelting furnace.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘May your eyes be open to your servant’s plea and to the plea of your people Israel, and may you listen to them whenever they cry out to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you singled them out from all the nations of the world to be your own inheritance, just as you declared through your servant Moses when you, Sovereign Lord, brought our ancestors out of Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Solomon had finished all these prayers and supplications to the Lord, he rose from before the altar of the Lord, where he had been kneeling with his hands spread out towards heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood and blessed the whole assembly of Israel in a loud voice, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Praise be to the Lord, who has given rest to his people Israel just as he promised. Not one word has failed of all the good promises he gave through his servant Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord our God be with us as he was with our ancestors; may he never leave us nor forsake us.
speaker: Narrator

text: May he turn our hearts to him, to walk in obedience to him and keep the commands, decrees and laws he gave our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: And may these words of mine, which I have prayed before the Lord, be near to the Lord our God day and night, that he may uphold the cause of his servant and the cause of his people Israel according to each day’s need,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that all the peoples of the earth may know that the Lord is God and that there is no other.
speaker: Narrator

text: And may your hearts be fully committed to the Lord our God, to live by his decrees and obey his commands, as at this time.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king and all Israel with him offered sacrifices before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon offered a sacrifice of fellowship offerings to the Lord: twenty-two thousand cattle and a hundred and twenty thousand sheep and goats. So the king and all the Israelites dedicated the temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that same day the king consecrated the middle part of the courtyard in front of the temple of the Lord, and there he offered burnt offerings, grain offerings and the fat of the fellowship offerings, because the bronze altar that stood before the Lord was too small to hold the burnt offerings, the grain offerings and the fat of the fellowship offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon observed the festival at that time, and all Israel with him – a vast assembly, people from Lebo Hamath to the Wadi of Egypt. They celebrated it before the Lord our God for seven days and seven days more, fourteen days in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the following day he sent the people away. They blessed the king and then went home, joyful and glad in heart for all the good things the Lord had done for his servant David and his people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Solomon had finished building the temple of the Lord and the royal palace, and had achieved all he had desired to do,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord appeared to him a second time, as he had appeared to him at Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said to him:
‘I have heard the prayer and plea you have made before me; I have consecrated this temple, which you have built, by putting my Name there for ever. My eyes and my heart will always be there.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘As for you, if you walk before me faithfully with integrity of heart and uprightness, as David your father did, and do all I command and observe my decrees and laws,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will establish your royal throne over Israel for ever, as I promised David your father when I said, “You shall never fail to have a successor on the throne of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But if you or your descendants turn away from me and do not observe the commands and decrees I have given you and go off to serve other gods and worship them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I will cut off Israel from the land I have given them and will reject this temple I have consecrated for my Name. Israel will then become a byword and an object of ridicule among all peoples.
speaker: Narrator

text: This temple will become a heap of rubble. All who pass by will be appalled and will scoff and say, “Why has the Lord done such a thing to this land and to this temple?”
speaker: Narrator

text: People will answer, “Because they have forsaken the Lord their God, who brought their ancestors out of Egypt, and have embraced other gods, worshipping and serving them – that is why the Lord brought all this disaster on them.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of twenty years, during which Solomon built these two buildings – the temple of the Lord and the royal palace –
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon gave twenty towns in Galilee to Hiram king of Tyre, because Hiram had supplied him with all the cedar and juniper and gold he wanted.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Hiram went from Tyre to see the towns that Solomon had given him, he was not pleased with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘What kind of towns are these you have given me, my brother?’ he asked. And he called them the Land of Kabul, a name they have to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Hiram had sent to the king 120 talents of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is the account of the forced labour King Solomon conscripted to build the Lord’s temple, his own palace, the terraces, the wall of Jerusalem, and Hazor, Megiddo and Gezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Pharaoh king of Egypt had attacked and captured Gezer. He had set it on fire. He killed its Canaanite inhabitants and then gave it as a wedding gift to his daughter, Solomon’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Solomon rebuilt Gezer.) He built up Lower Beth Horon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Baalath, and Tadmor in the desert, within his land,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as all his store cities and the towns for his chariots and for his horses – whatever he desired to build in Jerusalem, in Lebanon and throughout all the territory he ruled.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were still people left from the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites (these peoples were not Israelites).
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon conscripted the descendants of all these peoples remaining in the land – whom the Israelites could not exterminate – to serve as slave labour, as it is to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Solomon did not make slaves of any of the Israelites; they were his fighting men, his government officials, his officers, his captains, and the commanders of his chariots and charioteers.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were also the chief officials in charge of Solomon’s projects – 550 officials supervising those who did the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Pharaoh’s daughter had come up from the City of David to the palace Solomon had built for her, he constructed the terraces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three times a year Solomon sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings on the altar he had built for the Lord, burning incense before the Lord along with them, and so fulfilled the temple obligations.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon also built ships at Ezion Geber, which is near Elath in Edom, on the shore of the Red Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hiram sent his men – sailors who knew the sea – to serve in the fleet with Solomon’s men.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sailed to Ophir and brought back 420 talents of gold, which they delivered to King Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the queen of Sheba heard about the fame of Solomon and his relationship to the Lord, she came to test Solomon with hard questions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arriving at Jerusalem with a very great caravan – with camels carrying spices, large quantities of gold, and precious stones – she came to Solomon and talked with him about all that she had on her mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon answered all her questions; nothing was too hard for the king to explain to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the queen of Sheba saw all the wisdom of Solomon and the palace he had built,
speaker: Narrator

text: the food on his table, the seating of his officials, the attending servants in their robes, his cupbearers, and the burnt offerings he made at the temple of the Lord, she was overwhelmed.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to the king, ‘The report I heard in my own country about your achievements and your wisdom is true.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I did not believe these things until I came and saw with my own eyes. Indeed, not even half was told me; in wisdom and wealth you have far exceeded the report I heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: How happy your people must be! How happy your officials, who continually stand before you and hear your wisdom!
speaker: Narrator

text: Praise be to the Lord your God, who has delighted in you and placed you on the throne of Israel. Because of the Lord’s eternal love for Israel, he has made you king to maintain justice and righteousness.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And she gave the king 120 talents of gold, large quantities of spices, and precious stones. Never again were so many spices brought in as those the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Hiram’s ships brought gold from Ophir; and from there they brought great cargoes of almug-wood and precious stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king used the almug-wood to make supports for the temple of the Lord and for the royal palace, and to make harps and lyres for the musicians. So much almug-wood has never been imported or seen since that day.)
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba all she desired and asked for, besides what he had given her out of his royal bounty. Then she left and returned with her retinue to her own country.
speaker: Narrator

text: The weight of the gold that Solomon received yearly was 666 talents,
speaker: Narrator

text: not including the revenues from merchants and traders and from all the Arabian kings and the governors of the territories.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon made two hundred large shields of hammered gold; six hundred shekels of gold went into each shield.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made three hundred small shields of hammered gold, with three minas of gold in each shield. The king put them in the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king made a great throne covered with ivory and overlaid with fine gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The throne had six steps, and its back had a rounded top. On both sides of the seat were armrests, with a lion standing beside each of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Twelve lions stood on the six steps, one at either end of each step. Nothing like it had ever been made for any other kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: All King Solomon’s goblets were gold, and all the household articles in the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon were pure gold. Nothing was made of silver, because silver was considered of little value in Solomon’s days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king had a fleet of trading ships at sea along with the ships of Hiram. Once every three years it returned carrying gold, silver and ivory, and apes and baboons.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon was greater in riches and wisdom than all the other kings of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole world sought audience with Solomon to hear the wisdom God had put in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Year after year, everyone who came brought a gift – articles of silver and gold, robes, weapons and spices, and horses and mules.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon accumulated chariots and horses; he had fourteen hundred chariots and twelve thousand horses, which he kept in the chariot cities and also with him in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king made silver as common in Jerusalem as stones, and cedar as plentiful as sycamore-fig trees in the foothills.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon’s horses were imported from Egypt and from Kue – the royal merchants purchased them from Kue at the current price.
speaker: Narrator

text: They imported a chariot from Egypt for six hundred shekels of silver, and a horse for a hundred and fifty. They also exported them to all the kings of the Hittites and of the Arameans.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon, however, loved many foreign women besides Pharaoh’s daughter – Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Sidonians and Hittites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were from nations about which the Lord had told the Israelites, ‘You must not intermarry with them, because they will surely turn your hearts after their gods.’ Nevertheless, Solomon held fast to them in love.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had seven hundred wives of royal birth and three hundred concubines, and his wives led him astray.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Solomon grew old, his wives turned his heart after other gods, and his heart was not fully devoted to the Lord his God, as the heart of David his father had been.
speaker: Narrator

text: He followed Ashtoreth the goddess of the Sidonians, and Molek the detestable god of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon did evil in the eyes of the Lord; he did not follow the Lord completely, as David his father had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: On a hill east of Jerusalem, Solomon built a high place for Chemosh the detestable god of Moab, and for Molek the detestable god of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did the same for all his foreign wives, who burned incense and offered sacrifices to their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord became angry with Solomon because his heart had turned away from the Lord, the God of Israel, who had appeared to him twice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although he had forbidden Solomon to follow other gods, Solomon did not keep the Lord’s command.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said to Solomon, ‘Since this is your attitude and you have not kept my covenant and my decrees, which I commanded you, I will most certainly tear the kingdom away from you and give it to one of your subordinates.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, for the sake of David your father, I will not do it during your lifetime. I will tear it out of the hand of your son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet I will not tear the whole kingdom from him, but will give him one tribe for the sake of David my servant and for the sake of Jerusalem, which I have chosen.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord raised up against Solomon an adversary, Hadad the Edomite, from the royal line of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Earlier when David was fighting with Edom, Joab the commander of the army, who had gone up to bury the dead, had struck down all the men in Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab and all the Israelites stayed there for six months, until they had destroyed all the men in Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Hadad, still only a boy, fled to Egypt with some Edomite officials who had served his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out from Midian and went to Paran. Then taking people from Paran with them, they went to Egypt, to Pharaoh king of Egypt, who gave Hadad a house and land and provided him with food.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh was so pleased with Hadad that he gave him a sister of his own wife, Queen Tahpenes, in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sister of Tahpenes bore him a son named Genubath, whom Tahpenes brought up in the royal palace. There Genubath lived with Pharaoh’s own children.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was in Egypt, Hadad heard that David rested with his ancestors and that Joab the commander of the army was also dead. Then Hadad said to Pharaoh, ‘Let me go, so that I may return to my own country.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘What have you lacked here that you want to go back to your own country?’ Pharaoh asked.
‘Nothing,’ Hadad replied, ‘but do let me go!’
speaker: Narrator

text: And God raised up against Solomon another adversary, Rezon son of Eliada, who had fled from his master, Hadadezer king of Zobah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David destroyed Zobah’s army, Rezon gathered a band of men around him and became their leader; they went to Damascus, where they settled and took control.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rezon was Israel’s adversary as long as Solomon lived, adding to the trouble caused by Hadad. So Rezon ruled in Aram and was hostile towards Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, Jeroboam son of Nebat rebelled against the king. He was one of Solomon’s officials, an Ephraimite from Zeredah, and his mother was a widow named Zeruah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is the account of how he rebelled against the king: Solomon had built the terraces and had filled in the gap in the wall of the city of David his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jeroboam was a man of standing, and when Solomon saw how well the young man did his work, he put him in charge of the whole labour force of the tribes of Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: About that time Jeroboam was going out of Jerusalem, and Ahijah the prophet of Shiloh met him on the way, wearing a new cloak. The two of them were alone out in the country,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Ahijah took hold of the new cloak he was wearing and tore it into twelve pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to Jeroboam, ‘Take ten pieces for yourself, for this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: “See, I am going to tear the kingdom out of Solomon’s hand and give you ten tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: But for the sake of my servant David and the city of Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, he will have one tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will do this because they have forsaken me and worshipped Ashtoreth the goddess of the Sidonians, Chemosh the god of the Moabites, and Molek the god of the Ammonites, and have not walked in obedience to me, nor done what is right in my eyes, nor kept my decrees and laws as David, Solomon’s father, did.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“But I will not take the whole kingdom out of Solomon’s hand; I have made him ruler all the days of his life for the sake of David my servant, whom I chose and who obeyed my commands and decrees.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take the kingdom from his son’s hands and give you ten tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give one tribe to his son so that David my servant may always have a lamp before me in Jerusalem, the city where I chose to put my Name.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, as for you, I will take you, and you will rule over all that your heart desires; you will be king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do whatever I command you and walk in obedience to me and do what is right in my eyes by obeying my decrees and commands, as David my servant did, I will be with you. I will build you a dynasty as enduring as the one I built for David and will give Israel to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will humble David’s descendants because of this, but not for ever.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon tried to kill Jeroboam, but Jeroboam fled to Egypt, to Shishak the king, and stayed there until Solomon’s death.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the other events of Solomon’s reign – all he did and the wisdom he displayed – are they not written in the book of the annals of Solomon?
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he rested with his ancestors and was buried in the city of David his father. And Rehoboam his son succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehoboam went to Shechem, for all Israel had gone there to make him king.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jeroboam son of Nebat heard this (he was still in Egypt, where he had fled from King Solomon), he returned from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sent for Jeroboam, and he and the whole assembly of Israel went to Rehoboam and said to him:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Your father put a heavy yoke on us, but now lighten the harsh labour and the heavy yoke he put on us, and we will serve you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehoboam answered, ‘Go away for three days and then come back to me.’ So the people went away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Rehoboam consulted the elders who had served his father Solomon during his lifetime. ‘How would you advise me to answer these people?’ he asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, ‘If today you will be a servant to these people and serve them and give them a favourable answer, they will always be your servants.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Rehoboam rejected the advice the elders gave him and consulted the young men who had grown up with him and were serving him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked them, ‘What is your advice? How should we answer these people who say to me, “Lighten the yoke your father put on us”?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The young men who had grown up with him replied, ‘These people have said to you, “Your father put a heavy yoke on us, but make our yoke lighter.” Now tell them, “My little finger is thicker than my father’s waist.
speaker: Narrator

text: My father laid on you a heavy yoke; I will make it even heavier. My father scourged you with whips; I will scourge you with scorpions.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days later Jeroboam and all the people returned to Rehoboam, as the king had said, ‘Come back to me in three days.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king answered the people harshly. Rejecting the advice given him by the elders,
speaker: Narrator

text: he followed the advice of the young men and said, ‘My father made your yoke heavy; I will make it even heavier. My father scourged you with whips; I will scourge you with scorpions.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king did not listen to the people, for this turn of events was from the Lord, to fulfil the word the Lord had spoken to Jeroboam son of Nebat through Ahijah the Shilonite.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When all Israel saw that the king refused to listen to them, they answered the king:
‘What share do we have in David,
    what part in Jesse’s son?
To your tents, Israel!
    Look after your own house, David!’
So the Israelites went home.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for the Israelites who were living in the towns of Judah, Rehoboam still ruled over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Rehoboam sent out Adoniram, who was in charge of forced labour, but all Israel stoned him to death. King Rehoboam, however, managed to get into his chariot and escape to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel has been in rebellion against the house of David to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the Israelites heard that Jeroboam had returned, they sent and called him to the assembly and made him king over all Israel. Only the tribe of Judah remained loyal to the house of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rehoboam arrived in Jerusalem, he mustered all Judah and the tribe of Benjamin – a hundred and eighty thousand able young men – to go to war against Israel and to regain the kingdom for Rehoboam son of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this word of God came to Shemaiah the man of God:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to Rehoboam son of Solomon king of Judah, to all Judah and Benjamin, and to the rest of the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord says: do not go up to fight against your brothers, the Israelites. Go home, every one of you, for this is my doing.”’ So they obeyed the word of the Lord and went home again, as the Lord had ordered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeroboam fortified Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim and lived there. From there he went out and built up Peniel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam thought to himself, ‘The kingdom is now likely to revert to the house of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: If these people go up to offer sacrifices at the temple of the Lord in Jerusalem, they will again give their allegiance to their lord, Rehoboam king of Judah. They will kill me and return to King Rehoboam.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After seeking advice, the king made two golden calves. He said to the people, ‘It is too much for you to go up to Jerusalem. Here are your gods, Israel, who brought you up out of Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text: One he set up in Bethel, and the other in Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this thing became a sin; the people came to worship the one at Bethel and went as far as Dan to worship the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam built shrines on high places and appointed priests from all sorts of people, even though they were not Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He instituted a festival on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, like the festival held in Judah, and offered sacrifices on the altar. This he did in Bethel, sacrificing to the calves he had made. And at Bethel he also installed priests at the high places he had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifteenth day of the eighth month, a month of his own choosing, he offered sacrifices on the altar he had built at Bethel. So he instituted the festival for the Israelites and went up to the altar to make offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the word of the Lord a man of God came from Judah to Bethel, as Jeroboam was standing by the altar to make an offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the word of the Lord he cried out against the altar: ‘Altar, altar! This is what the Lord says: “A son named Josiah will be born to the house of David. On you he will sacrifice the priests of the high places who make offerings here, and human bones will be burned on you.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day the man of God gave a sign: ‘This is the sign the Lord has declared: the altar will be split apart and the ashes on it will be poured out.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Jeroboam heard what the man of God cried out against the altar at Bethel, he stretched out his hand from the altar and said, ‘Seize him!’ But the hand he stretched out towards the man shrivelled up, so that he could not pull it back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, the altar was split apart and its ashes poured out according to the sign given by the man of God by the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to the man of God, ‘Intercede with the Lord your God and pray for me that my hand may be restored.’ So the man of God interceded with the Lord, and the king’s hand was restored and became as it was before.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to the man of God, ‘Come home with me for a meal, and I will give you a gift.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man of God answered the king, ‘Even if you were to give me half your possessions, I would not go with you, nor would I eat bread or drink water here.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I was commanded by the word of the Lord: “You must not eat bread or drink water or return by the way you came.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took another road and did not return by the way he had come to Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a certain old prophet living in Bethel, whose sons came and told him all that the man of God had done there that day. They also told their father what he had said to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their father asked them, ‘Which way did he go?’ And his sons showed him which road the man of God from Judah had taken.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to his sons, ‘Saddle the donkey for me.’ And when they had saddled the donkey for him, he mounted it
speaker: Narrator

text:
and rode after the man of God. He found him sitting under an oak tree and asked, ‘Are you the man of God who came from Judah?’
‘I am,’ he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the prophet said to him, ‘Come home with me and eat.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The man of God said, ‘I cannot turn back and go with you, nor can I eat bread or drink water with you in this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have been told by the word of the Lord: “You must not eat bread or drink water there or return by the way you came.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The old prophet answered, ‘I too am a prophet, as you are. And an angel said to me by the word of the Lord: “Bring him back with you to your house so that he may eat bread and drink water.”’ (But he was lying to him.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So the man of God returned with him and ate and drank in his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were sitting at the table, the word of the Lord came to the old prophet who had brought him back.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cried out to the man of God who had come from Judah, ‘This is what the Lord says: “You have defied the word of the Lord and have not kept the command the Lord your God gave you.
