speaker: Narrator

text: You came back and ate bread and drank water in the place where he told you not to eat or drink. Therefore your body will not be buried in the tomb of your ancestors.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man of God had finished eating and drinking, the prophet who had brought him back saddled his donkey for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he went on his way, a lion met him on the road and killed him, and his body was left lying on the road, with both the donkey and the lion standing beside it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some people who passed by saw the body lying there, with the lion standing beside the body, and they went and reported it in the city where the old prophet lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the prophet who had brought him back from his journey heard of it, he said, ‘It is the man of God who defied the word of the Lord. The Lord has given him over to the lion, which has mauled him and killed him, as the word of the Lord had warned him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet said to his sons, ‘Saddle the donkey for me,’ and they did so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went out and found the body lying on the road, with the donkey and the lion standing beside it. The lion had neither eaten the body nor mauled the donkey.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the prophet picked up the body of the man of God, laid it on the donkey, and brought it back to his own city to mourn for him and bury him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he laid the body in his own tomb, and they mourned over him and said, ‘Alas, my brother!’
speaker: Narrator

text: After burying him, he said to his sons, ‘When I die, bury me in the grave where the man of God is buried; lay my bones beside his bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the message he declared by the word of the Lord against the altar in Bethel and against all the shrines on the high places in the towns of Samaria will certainly come true.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Even after this, Jeroboam did not change his evil ways, but once more appointed priests for the high places from all sorts of people. Anyone who wanted to become a priest he consecrated for the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the sin of the house of Jeroboam that led to its downfall and to its destruction from the face of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Abijah son of Jeroboam became ill,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Jeroboam said to his wife, ‘Go, disguise yourself, so that you won’t be recognised as the wife of Jeroboam. Then go to Shiloh. Ahijah the prophet is there – the one who told me I would be king over this people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take ten loaves of bread with you, some cakes and a jar of honey, and go to him. He will tell you what will happen to the boy.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Jeroboam’s wife did what he said and went to Ahijah’s house in Shiloh.
Now Ahijah could not see; his sight was gone because of his age.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord had told Ahijah, ‘Jeroboam’s wife is coming to ask you about her son, for he is ill, and you are to give her such and such an answer. When she arrives, she will pretend to be someone else.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So when Ahijah heard the sound of her footsteps at the door, he said, ‘Come in, wife of Jeroboam. Why this pretence? I have been sent to you with bad news.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go, tell Jeroboam that this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: “I raised you up from among the people and appointed you ruler over my people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tore the kingdom away from the house of David and gave it to you, but you have not been like my servant David, who kept my commands and followed me with all his heart, doing only what was right in my eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have done more evil than all who lived before you. You have made for yourself other gods, idols made of metal; you have aroused my anger and turned your back on me.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Because of this, I am going to bring disaster on the house of Jeroboam. I will cut off from Jeroboam every last male in Israel – slave or free. I will burn up the house of Jeroboam as one burns dung, until it is all gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dogs will eat those belonging to Jeroboam who die in the city, and the birds will feed on those who die in the country. The Lord has spoken!”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘As for you, go back home. When you set foot in your city, the boy will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel will mourn for him and bury him. He is the only one belonging to Jeroboam who will be buried, because he is the only one in the house of Jeroboam in whom the Lord, the God of Israel, has found anything good.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The Lord will raise up for himself a king over Israel who will cut off the family of Jeroboam. Even now this is beginning to happen.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord will strike Israel, so that it will be like a reed swaying in the water. He will uproot Israel from this good land that he gave to their ancestors and scatter them beyond the River Euphrates, because they aroused the Lord’s anger by making Asherah poles.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he will give Israel up because of the sins Jeroboam has committed and has caused Israel to commit.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeroboam’s wife got up and left and went to Tirzah. As soon as she stepped over the threshold of the house, the boy died.
speaker: Narrator

text: They buried him, and all Israel mourned for him, as the Lord had said through his servant the prophet Ahijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The other events of Jeroboam’s reign, his wars and how he ruled, are written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reigned for twenty-two years and then rested with his ancestors. And Nadab his son succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehoboam son of Solomon was king in Judah. He was forty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned for seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city the Lord had chosen out of all the tribes of Israel in which to put his Name. His mother’s name was Naamah; she was an Ammonite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah did evil in the eyes of the Lord. By the sins they committed they stirred up his jealous anger more than those who were before them had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also set up for themselves high places, sacred stones and Asherah poles on every high hill and under every spreading tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were even male shrine-prostitutes in the land; the people engaged in all the detestable practices of the nations the Lord had driven out before the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifth year of King Rehoboam, Shishak king of Egypt attacked Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carried off the treasures of the temple of the Lord and the treasures of the royal palace. He took everything, including all the gold shields Solomon had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Rehoboam made bronze shields to replace them and assigned these to the commanders of the guard on duty at the entrance to the royal palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the king went to the Lord’s temple, the guards bore the shields, and afterwards they returned them to the guardroom.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the other events of Rehoboam’s reign, and all he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: There was continual warfare between Rehoboam and Jeroboam.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Rehoboam rested with his ancestors and was buried with them in the City of David. His mother’s name was Naamah; she was an Ammonite. And Abijah his son succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the eighteenth year of the reign of Jeroboam son of Nebat, Abijah became king of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he reigned in Jerusalem for three years. His mother’s name was Maakah daughter of Abishalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He committed all the sins his father had done before him; his heart was not fully devoted to the Lord his God, as the heart of David his forefather had been.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, for David’s sake the Lord his God gave him a lamp in Jerusalem by raising up a son to succeed him and by making Jerusalem strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: For David had done what was right in the eyes of the Lord and had not failed to keep any of the Lord’s commands all the days of his life – except in the case of Uriah the Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was war between Abijah and Jeroboam throughout Abijah’s lifetime.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the other events of Abijah’s reign, and all he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah? There was war between Abijah and Jeroboam.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abijah rested with his ancestors and was buried in the City of David. And Asa his son succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twentieth year of Jeroboam king of Israel, Asa became king of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he reigned in Jerusalem for forty-one years. His grandmother’s name was Maakah daughter of Abishalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, as his father David had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: He expelled the male shrine-prostitutes from the land and got rid of all the idols his ancestors had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: He even deposed his grandmother Maakah from her position as queen mother, because she had made a repulsive image for the worship of Asherah. Asa cut it down and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although he did not remove the high places, Asa’s heart was fully committed to the Lord all his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought into the temple of the Lord the silver and gold and the articles that he and his father had dedicated.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was war between Asa and Baasha king of Israel throughout their reigns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Baasha king of Israel went up against Judah and fortified Ramah to prevent anyone from leaving or entering the territory of Asa king of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa then took all the silver and gold that was left in the treasuries of the Lord’s temple and of his own palace. He entrusted it to his officials and sent them to Ben-Hadad son of Tabrimmon, the son of Hezion, the king of Aram, who was ruling in Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Let there be a treaty between me and you,’ he said, ‘as there was between my father and your father. See, I am sending you a gift of silver and gold. Now break your treaty with Baasha king of Israel so that he will withdraw from me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-Hadad agreed with King Asa and sent the commanders of his forces against the towns of Israel. He conquered Ijon, Dan, Abel Beth Maakah and all Kinnereth in addition to Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Baasha heard this, he stopped building Ramah and withdrew to Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Asa issued an order to all Judah – no one was exempt – and they carried away from Ramah the stones and timber Baasha had been using there. With them King Asa built up Geba in Benjamin, and also Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for all the other events of Asa’s reign, all his achievements, all he did and the cities he built, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah? In his old age, however, his feet became diseased.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Asa rested with his ancestors and was buried with them in the city of his father David. And Jehoshaphat his son succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nadab son of Jeroboam became king of Israel in the second year of Asa king of Judah, and he reigned over Israel for two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord, following the ways of his father and committing the same sin his father had caused Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Baasha son of Ahijah from the tribe of Issachar plotted against him, and he struck him down at Gibbethon, a Philistine town, while Nadab and all Israel were besieging it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Baasha killed Nadab in the third year of Asa king of Judah and succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he began to reign, he killed Jeroboam’s whole family. He did not leave Jeroboam anyone that breathed, but destroyed them all, according to the word of the Lord given through his servant Ahijah the Shilonite.
speaker: Narrator

text: This happened because of the sins Jeroboam had committed and had caused Israel to commit, and because he aroused the anger of the Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the other events of Nadab’s reign, and all he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: There was war between Asa and Baasha king of Israel throughout their reigns.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third year of Asa king of Judah, Baasha son of Ahijah became king of all Israel in Tirzah, and he reigned for twenty-four years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord, following the ways of Jeroboam and committing the same sin Jeroboam had caused Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to Jehu son of Hanani concerning Baasha:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I lifted you up from the dust and appointed you ruler over my people Israel, but you followed the ways of Jeroboam and caused my people Israel to sin and to arouse my anger by their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I am about to wipe out Baasha and his house, and I will make your house like that of Jeroboam son of Nebat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dogs will eat those belonging to Baasha who die in the city, and birds will feed on those who die in the country.’
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the other events of Baasha’s reign, what he did and his achievements, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Baasha rested with his ancestors and was buried in Tirzah. And Elah his son succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the word of the Lord came through the prophet Jehu son of Hanani to Baasha and his house, because of all the evil he had done in the eyes of the Lord, arousing his anger by the things he did, becoming like the house of Jeroboam – and also because he destroyed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twenty-sixth year of Asa king of Judah, Elah son of Baasha became king of Israel, and he reigned in Tirzah for two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zimri, one of his officials, who had command of half his chariots, plotted against him. Elah was in Tirzah at the time, getting drunk in the home of Arza, the palace administrator at Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zimri came in, struck him down and killed him in the twenty-seventh year of Asa king of Judah. Then he succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he began to reign and was seated on the throne, he killed off Baasha’s whole family. He did not spare a single male, whether relative or friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Zimri destroyed the whole family of Baasha, in accordance with the word of the Lord spoken against Baasha through the prophet Jehu –
speaker: Narrator

text: because of all the sins Baasha and his son Elah had committed and had caused Israel to commit, so that they aroused the anger of the Lord, the God of Israel, by their worthless idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the other events of Elah’s reign, and all he did, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twenty-seventh year of Asa king of Judah, Zimri reigned in Tirzah for seven days. The army was encamped near Gibbethon, a Philistine town.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites in the camp heard that Zimri had plotted against the king and murdered him, they proclaimed Omri, the commander of the army, king over Israel that very day there in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Omri and all the Israelites with him withdrew from Gibbethon and laid siege to Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Zimri saw that the city was taken, he went into the citadel of the royal palace and set the palace on fire around him. So he died,
speaker: Narrator

text: because of the sins he had committed, doing evil in the eyes of the Lord and following the ways of Jeroboam and committing the same sin Jeroboam had caused Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the other events of Zimri’s reign, and the rebellion he carried out, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Israel were split into two factions; half supported Tibni son of Ginath for king, and the other half supported Omri.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Omri’s followers proved stronger than those of Tibni son of Ginath. So Tibni died and Omri became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-first year of Asa king of Judah, Omri became king of Israel, and he reigned for twelve years, six of them in Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He bought the hill of Samaria from Shemer for two talents of silver and built a city on the hill, calling it Samaria, after Shemer, the name of the former owner of the hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Omri did evil in the eyes of the Lord and sinned more than all those before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He followed completely the ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat, committing the same sin Jeroboam had caused Israel to commit, so that they aroused the anger of the Lord, the God of Israel, by their worthless idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the other events of Omri’s reign, what he did and the things he achieved, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Omri rested with his ancestors and was buried in Samaria. And Ahab his son succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-eighth year of Asa king of Judah, Ahab son of Omri became king of Israel, and he reigned in Samaria over Israel for twenty-two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab son of Omri did more evil in the eyes of the Lord than any of those before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He not only considered it trivial to commit the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, but he also married Jezebel daughter of Ethbaal king of the Sidonians, and began to serve Baal and worship him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set up an altar for Baal in the temple of Baal that he built in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab also made an Asherah pole and did more to arouse the anger of the Lord, the God of Israel, than did all the kings of Israel before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In Ahab’s time, Hiel of Bethel rebuilt Jericho. He laid its foundations at the cost of his firstborn son Abiram, and he set up its gates at the cost of his youngest son Segub, in accordance with the word of the Lord spoken by Joshua son of Nun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elijah the Tishbite, from Tishbe in Gilead, said to Ahab, ‘As the Lord, the God of Israel, lives, whom I serve, there will be neither dew nor rain in the next few years except at my word.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Leave here, turn eastward and hide in the Kerith Ravine, east of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will drink from the brook, and I have instructed the ravens to supply you with food there.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So he did what the Lord had told him. He went to the Kerith Ravine, east of the Jordan, and stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ravens brought him bread and meat in the morning and bread and meat in the evening, and he drank from the brook.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later the brook dried up because there had been no rain in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to him:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Go at once to Zarephath in the region of Sidon and stay there. I have instructed a widow there to supply you with food.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went to Zarephath. When he came to the town gate, a widow was there gathering sticks. He called to her and asked, ‘Would you bring me a little water in a jar so I may have a drink?’
speaker: Narrator

text: As she was going to get it, he called, ‘And bring me, please, a piece of bread.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘As surely as the Lord your God lives,’ she replied, ‘I don’t have any bread – only a handful of flour in a jar and a little olive oil in a jug. I am gathering a few sticks to take home and make a meal for myself and my son, that we may eat it – and die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said to her, ‘Don’t be afraid. Go home and do as you have said. But first make a small loaf of bread for me from what you have and bring it to me, and then make something for yourself and your son.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: “The jar of flour will not be used up and the jug of oil will not run dry until the day the Lord sends rain on the land.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: She went away and did as Elijah had told her. So there was food every day for Elijah and for the woman and her family.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the jar of flour was not used up and the jug of oil did not run dry, in keeping with the word of the Lord spoken by Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later the son of the woman who owned the house became ill. He grew worse and worse, and finally stopped breathing.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to Elijah, ‘What do you have against me, man of God? Did you come to remind me of my sin and kill my son?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Give me your son,’ Elijah replied. He took him from her arms, carried him to the upper room where he was staying, and laid him on his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he cried out to the Lord, ‘Lord my God, have you brought tragedy even on this widow I am staying with, by causing her son to die?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he stretched himself out on the boy three times and cried out to the Lord, ‘Lord my God, let this boy’s life return to him!’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord heard Elijah’s cry, and the boy’s life returned to him, and he lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah picked up the child and carried him down from the room into the house. He gave him to his mother and said, ‘Look, your son is alive!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman said to Elijah, ‘Now I know that you are a man of God and that the word of the Lord from your mouth is the truth.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After a long time, in the third year, the word of the Lord came to Elijah: ‘Go and present yourself to Ahab, and I will send rain on the land.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Elijah went to present himself to Ahab.
Now the famine was severe in Samaria,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Ahab had summoned Obadiah, his palace administrator. (Obadiah was a devout believer in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Jezebel was killing off the Lord’s prophets, Obadiah had taken a hundred prophets and hidden them in two caves, fifty in each, and had supplied them with food and water.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab had said to Obadiah, ‘Go through the land to all the springs and valleys. Maybe we can find some grass to keep the horses and mules alive so we will not have to kill any of our animals.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they divided the land they were to cover, Ahab going in one direction and Obadiah in another.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Obadiah was walking along, Elijah met him. Obadiah recognised him, bowed down to the ground, and said, ‘Is it really you, my lord Elijah?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Yes,’ he replied. ‘Go tell your master, “Elijah is here.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘What have I done wrong,’ asked Obadiah, ‘that you are handing your servant over to Ahab to be put to death?
speaker: Narrator

text: As surely as the Lord your God lives, there is not a nation or kingdom where my master has not sent someone to look for you. And whenever a nation or kingdom claimed you were not there, he made them swear they could not find you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now you tell me to go to my master and say, “Elijah is here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I don’t know where the Spirit of the Lord may carry you when I leave you. If I go and tell Ahab and he doesn’t find you, he will kill me. Yet I your servant have worshipped the Lord since my youth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Haven’t you heard, my lord, what I did while Jezebel was killing the prophets of the Lord? I hid a hundred of the Lord’s prophets in two caves, fifty in each, and supplied them with food and water.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now you tell me to go to my master and say, “Elijah is here.” He will kill me!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said, ‘As the Lord Almighty lives, whom I serve, I will surely present myself to Ahab today.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Obadiah went to meet Ahab and told him, and Ahab went to meet Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw Elijah, he said to him, ‘Is that you, you troubler of Israel?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I have not made trouble for Israel,’ Elijah replied. ‘But you and your father’s family have. You have abandoned the Lord’s commands and have followed the Baals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now summon the people from all over Israel to meet me on Mount Carmel. And bring the four hundred and fifty prophets of Baal and the four hundred prophets of Asherah, who eat at Jezebel’s table.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahab sent word throughout all Israel and assembled the prophets on Mount Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elijah went before the people and said, ‘How long will you waver between two opinions? If the Lord is God, follow him; but if Baal is God, follow him.’
But the people said nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elijah said to them, ‘I am the only one of the Lord’s prophets left, but Baal has four hundred and fifty prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get two bulls for us. Let Baal’s prophets choose one for themselves, and let them cut it into pieces and put it on the wood but not set fire to it. I will prepare the other bull and put it on the wood but not set fire to it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you call on the name of your god, and I will call on the name of the Lord. The god who answers by fire – he is God.’
Then all the people said, ‘What you say is good.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said to the prophets of Baal, ‘Choose one of the bulls and prepare it first, since there are so many of you. Call on the name of your god, but do not light the fire.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they took the bull that was given to them and prepared it.
Then they called on the name of Baal from morning till noon. ‘Baal, answer us!’ they shouted. But there was no response; no one answered. And they danced around the altar they had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: At noon Elijah began to taunt them. ‘Shout louder!’ he said. ‘Surely he is a god! Perhaps he is deep in thought, or busy, or travelling. Maybe he is sleeping and must be awakened.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they shouted louder and slashed themselves with swords and spears, as was their custom, until their blood flowed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Midday passed, and they continued their frantic prophesying until the time for the evening sacrifice. But there was no response, no one answered, no one paid attention.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elijah said to all the people, ‘Come here to me.’ They came to him, and he repaired the altar of the Lord, which had been torn down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah took twelve stones, one for each of the tribes descended from Jacob, to whom the word of the Lord had come, saying, ‘Your name shall be Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: With the stones he built an altar in the name of the Lord, and he dug a trench round it large enough to hold two seahs of seed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He arranged the wood, cut the bull into pieces and laid it on the wood. Then he said to them, ‘Fill four large jars with water and pour it on the offering and on the wood.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Do it again,’ he said, and they did it again.
‘Do it a third time,’ he ordered, and they did it the third time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water ran down around the altar and even filled the trench.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the time of sacrifice, the prophet Elijah stepped forward and prayed: ‘Lord, the God of Abraham, Isaac and Israel, let it be known today that you are God in Israel and that I am your servant and have done all these things at your command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Answer me, Lord, answer me, so these people will know that you, Lord, are God, and that you are turning their hearts back again.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the fire of the Lord fell and burned up the sacrifice, the wood, the stones and the soil, and also licked up the water in the trench.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people saw this, they fell prostrate and cried, ‘The Lord – he is God! The Lord – he is God!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elijah commanded them, ‘Seize the prophets of Baal. Don’t let anyone get away!’ They seized them, and Elijah had them brought down to the Kishon Valley and slaughtered there.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elijah said to Ahab, ‘Go, eat and drink, for there is the sound of a heavy rain.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahab went off to eat and drink, but Elijah climbed to the top of Carmel, bent down to the ground and put his face between his knees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Go and look toward the sea,’ he told his servant. And he went up and looked.
‘There is nothing there,’ he said.
Seven times Elijah said, ‘Go back.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The seventh time the servant reported, ‘A cloud as small as a man’s hand is rising from the sea.’
So Elijah said, ‘Go and tell Ahab, “Hitch up your chariot and go down before the rain stops you.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the sky grew black with clouds, the wind rose, a heavy rainstorm came on and Ahab rode off to Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The power of the Lord came on Elijah and, tucking his cloak into his belt, he ran ahead of Ahab all the way to Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ahab told Jezebel everything Elijah had done and how he had killed all the prophets with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jezebel sent a messenger to Elijah to say, ‘May the gods deal with me, be it ever so severely, if by this time tomorrow I do not make your life like that of one of them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah was afraid and ran for his life. When he came to Beersheba in Judah, he left his servant there,
speaker: Narrator

text: while he himself went a day’s journey into the wilderness. He came to a broom bush, sat down under it and prayed that he might die. ‘I have had enough, Lord,’ he said. ‘Take my life; I am no better than my ancestors.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he lay down under the bush and fell asleep.
All at once an angel touched him and said, ‘Get up and eat.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked around, and there by his head was some bread baked over hot coals, and a jar of water. He ate and drank and then lay down again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord came back a second time and touched him and said, ‘Get up and eat, for the journey is too much for you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So he got up and ate and drank. Strengthened by that food, he travelled for forty days and forty nights until he reached Horeb, the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There he went into a cave and spent the night.
And the word of the Lord came to him: ‘What are you doing here, Elijah?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, ‘I have been very zealous for the Lord God Almighty. The Israelites have rejected your covenant, torn down your altars, and put your prophets to death with the sword. I am the only one left, and now they are trying to kill me too.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said, ‘Go out and stand on the mountain in the presence of the Lord, for the Lord is about to pass by.’
Then a great and powerful wind tore the mountains apart and shattered the rocks before the Lord, but the Lord was not in the wind. After the wind there was an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the earthquake came a fire, but the Lord was not in the fire. And after the fire came a gentle whisper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Elijah heard it, he pulled his cloak over his face and went out and stood at the mouth of the cave.
Then a voice said to him, ‘What are you doing here, Elijah?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, ‘I have been very zealous for the Lord God Almighty. The Israelites have rejected your covenant, torn down your altars, and put your prophets to death with the sword. I am the only one left, and now they are trying to kill me too.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, ‘Go back the way you came, and go to the Desert of Damascus. When you get there, anoint Hazael king over Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, anoint Jehu son of Nimshi king over Israel, and anoint Elisha son of Shaphat from Abel Meholah to succeed you as prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu will put to death any who escape the sword of Hazael, and Elisha will put to death any who escape the sword of Jehu.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet I reserve seven thousand in Israel – all whose knees have not bowed down to Baal and whose mouths have not kissed him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Elijah went from there and found Elisha son of Shaphat. He was ploughing with twelve yoke of oxen, and he himself was driving the twelfth pair. Elijah went up to him and threw his cloak around him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elisha then left his oxen and ran after Elijah. ‘Let me kiss my father and mother goodbye,’ he said, ‘and then I will come with you.’
‘Go back,’ Elijah replied. ‘What have I done to you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Elisha left him and went back. He took his yoke of oxen and slaughtered them. He burned the ploughing equipment to cook the meat and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he set out to follow Elijah and became his servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ben-Hadad king of Aram mustered his entire army. Accompanied by thirty-two kings with their horses and chariots, he went up and besieged Samaria and attacked it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent messengers into the city to Ahab king of Israel, saying, ‘This is what Ben-Hadad says:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your silver and gold are mine, and the best of your wives and children are mine.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel answered, ‘Just as you say, my lord the king. I and all I have are yours.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The messengers came again and said, ‘This is what Ben-Hadad says: “I sent to demand your silver and gold, your wives and your children.
speaker: Narrator

text: But about this time tomorrow I am going to send my officials to search your palace and the houses of your officials. They will seize everything you value and carry it away.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel summoned all the elders of the land and said to them, ‘See how this man is looking for trouble! When he sent for my wives and my children, my silver and my gold, I did not refuse him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders and the people all answered, ‘Don’t listen to him or agree to his demands.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So he replied to Ben-Hadad’s messengers, ‘Tell my lord the king, “Your servant will do all you demanded the first time, but this demand I cannot meet.”’ They left and took the answer back to Ben-Hadad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ben-Hadad sent another message to Ahab: ‘May the gods deal with me, be it ever so severely, if enough dust remains in Samaria to give each of my men a handful.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel answered, ‘Tell him: “One who puts on his armour should not boast like one who takes it off.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-Hadad heard this message while he and the kings were drinking in their tents, and he ordered his men: ‘Prepare to attack.’ So they prepared to attack the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile a prophet came to Ahab king of Israel and announced, ‘This is what the Lord says: “Do you see this vast army? I will give it into your hand today, and then you will know that I am the Lord.”’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘But who will do this?’ asked Ahab.
The prophet replied, ‘This is what the Lord says: “The junior officers under the provincial commanders will do it.”’
‘And who will start the battle?’ he asked.
The prophet answered, ‘You will.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahab summoned the 232 junior officers under the provincial commanders. Then he assembled the rest of the Israelites, 7,000 in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out at noon while Ben-Hadad and the 32 kings allied with him were in their tents getting drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The junior officers under the provincial commanders went out first.
Now Ben-Hadad had dispatched scouts, who reported, ‘Men are advancing from Samaria.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, ‘If they have come out for peace, take them alive; if they have come out for war, take them alive.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The junior officers under the provincial commanders marched out of the city with the army behind them
speaker: Narrator

text: and each one struck down his opponent. At that, the Arameans fled, with the Israelites in pursuit. But Ben-Hadad king of Aram escaped on horseback with some of his horsemen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel advanced and overpowered the horses and chariots and inflicted heavy losses on the Arameans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards, the prophet came to the king of Israel and said, ‘Strengthen your position and see what must be done, because next spring the king of Aram will attack you again.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the officials of the king of Aram advised him, ‘Their gods are gods of the hills. That is why they were too strong for us. But if we fight them on the plains, surely we will be stronger than they.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this: remove all the kings from their commands and replace them with other officers.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must also raise an army like the one you lost – horse for horse and chariot for chariot – so we can fight Israel on the plains. Then surely we will be stronger than they.’ He agreed with them and acted accordingly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next spring Ben-Hadad mustered the Arameans and went up to Aphek to fight against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites were also mustered and given provisions, they marched out to meet them. The Israelites camped opposite them like two small flocks of goats, while the Arameans covered the countryside.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man of God came up and told the king of Israel, ‘This is what the Lord says: “Because the Arameans think the Lord is a god of the hills and not a god of the valleys, I will deliver this vast army into your hands, and you will know that I am the Lord.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days they camped opposite each other, and on the seventh day the battle was joined. The Israelites inflicted a hundred thousand casualties on the Aramean foot soldiers in one day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of them escaped to the city of Aphek, where the wall collapsed on twenty-seven thousand of them. And Ben-Hadad fled to the city and hid in an inner room.
speaker: Narrator

text: His officials said to him, ‘Look, we have heard that the kings of Israel are merciful. Let us go to the king of Israel with sackcloth round our waists and ropes round our heads. Perhaps he will spare your life.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wearing sackcloth round their waists and ropes round their heads, they went to the king of Israel and said, ‘Your servant Ben-Hadad says: “Please let me live.”’
The king answered, ‘Is he still alive? He is my brother.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The men took this as a good sign and were quick to pick up his word. ‘Yes, your brother Ben-Hadad!’ they said.
‘Go and get him,’ the king said. When Ben-Hadad came out, Ahab brought him up into his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I will return the cities my father took from your father,’ Ben-Hadad offered. ‘You may set up your own market areas in Damascus, as my father did in Samaria.’
Ahab said, ‘On the basis of a treaty I will set you free.’ So he made a treaty with him, and let him go.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the word of the Lord one of the company of the prophets said to his companion, ‘Strike me with your weapon,’ but he refused.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the prophet said, ‘Because you have not obeyed the Lord, as soon as you leave me a lion will kill you.’ And after the man went away, a lion found him and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet found another man and said, ‘Strike me, please.’ So the man struck him and wounded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet went and stood by the road waiting for the king. He disguised himself with his headband down over his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the king passed by, the prophet called out to him, ‘Your servant went into the thick of the battle, and someone came to me with a captive and said, “Guard this man. If he is missing, it will be your life for his life, or you must pay a talent of silver.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
While your servant was busy here and there, the man disappeared.’
‘That is your sentence,’ the king of Israel said. ‘You have pronounced it yourself.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet quickly removed the headband from his eyes, and the king of Israel recognised him as one of the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the king, ‘This is what the Lord says: “You have set free a man I had determined should die. Therefore it is your life for his life, your people for his people.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Sullen and angry, the king of Israel went to his palace in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later there was an incident involving a vineyard belonging to Naboth the Jezreelite. The vineyard was in Jezreel, close to the palace of Ahab king of Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab said to Naboth, ‘Let me have your vineyard to use for a vegetable garden, since it is close to my palace. In exchange I will give you a better vineyard or, if you prefer, I will pay you whatever it is worth.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Naboth replied, ‘The Lord forbid that I should give you the inheritance of my ancestors.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahab went home, sullen and angry because Naboth the Jezreelite had said, ‘I will not give you the inheritance of my ancestors.’ He lay on his bed sulking and refused to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: His wife Jezebel came in and asked him, ‘Why are you so sullen? Why won’t you eat?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered her, ‘Because I said to Naboth the Jezreelite, “Sell me your vineyard; or if you prefer, I will give you another vineyard in its place.” But he said, “I will not give you my vineyard.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jezebel his wife said, ‘Is this how you act as king over Israel? Get up and eat! Cheer up. I’ll get you the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So she wrote letters in Ahab’s name, placed his seal on them, and sent them to the elders and nobles who lived in Naboth’s city with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In those letters she wrote:
‘Proclaim a day of fasting and give Naboth a prominent seat among the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But put two scoundrels opposite him and get them to bring charges that he has cursed both God and the king. Then take him out and stone him to death.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the elders and nobles who lived in Naboth’s city did as Jezebel directed in the letters she had written to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They proclaimed a fast and seated Naboth in a prominent place among the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then two scoundrels came and sat opposite him and brought charges against Naboth before the people, saying, ‘Naboth has cursed both God and the king.’ So they took him outside the city and stoned him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they sent word to Jezebel: ‘Naboth has been stoned to death.’
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned to death, she said to Ahab, ‘Get up and take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite that he refused to sell you. He is no longer alive, but dead.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, he got up and went down to take possession of Naboth’s vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Go down to meet Ahab king of Israel, who rules in Samaria. He is now in Naboth’s vineyard, where he has gone to take possession of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to him, “This is what the Lord says: have you not murdered a man and seized his property?” Then say to him, “This is what the Lord says: in the place where dogs licked up Naboth’s blood, dogs will lick up your blood – yes, yours!”’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahab said to Elijah, ‘So you have found me, my enemy!’
‘I have found you,’ he answered, ‘because you have sold yourself to do evil in the eyes of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He says, “I am going to bring disaster on you. I will wipe out your descendants and cut off from Ahab every last male in Israel – slave or free.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your house like that of Jeroboam son of Nebat and that of Baasha son of Ahijah, because you have aroused my anger and have caused Israel to sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘And also concerning Jezebel the Lord says: “Dogs will devour Jezebel by the wall of Jezreel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Dogs will eat those belonging to Ahab who die in the city, and the birds will feed on those who die in the country.’
speaker: Narrator

text: (There was never anyone like Ahab, who sold himself to do evil in the eyes of the Lord, urged on by Jezebel his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: He behaved in the vilest manner by going after idols, like the Amorites the Lord drove out before Israel.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahab heard these words, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth and fasted. He lay in sackcloth and went around meekly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Have you noticed how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Because he has humbled himself, I will not bring this disaster in his day, but I will bring it on his house in the days of his son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For three years there was no war between Aram and Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the third year Jehoshaphat king of Judah went down to see the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel had said to his officials, ‘Don’t you know that Ramoth Gilead belongs to us and yet we are doing nothing to retake it from the king of Aram?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he asked Jehoshaphat, ‘Will you go with me to fight against Ramoth Gilead?’
Jehoshaphat replied to the king of Israel, ‘I am as you are, my people as your people, my horses as your horses.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoshaphat also said to the king of Israel, ‘First seek the counsel of the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the king of Israel brought together the prophets – about four hundred men – and asked them, ‘Shall I go to war against Ramoth Gilead, or shall I refrain?’
‘Go,’ they answered, ‘for the Lord will give it into the king’s hand.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoshaphat asked, ‘Is there no longer a prophet of the Lord here whom we can enquire of?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king of Israel answered Jehoshaphat, ‘There is still one prophet through whom we can enquire of the Lord, but I hate him because he never prophesies anything good about me, but always bad. He is Micaiah son of Imlah.’
‘The king should not say such a thing,’ Jehoshaphat replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Israel called one of his officials and said, ‘Bring Micaiah son of Imlah at once.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Dressed in their royal robes, the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah were sitting on their thrones at the threshing-floor by the entrance of the gate of Samaria, with all the prophets prophesying before them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Zedekiah son of Kenaanah had made iron horns and he declared, ‘This is what the Lord says: “With these you will gore the Arameans until they are destroyed.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: All the other prophets were prophesying the same thing. ‘Attack Ramoth Gilead and be victorious,’ they said, ‘for the Lord will give it into the king’s hand.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The messenger who had gone to summon Micaiah said to him, ‘Look, the other prophets without exception are predicting success for the king. Let your word agree with theirs, and speak favourably.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Micaiah said, ‘As surely as the Lord lives, I can tell him only what the Lord tells me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he arrived, the king asked him, ‘Micaiah, shall we go to war against Ramoth Gilead, or not?’
‘Attack and be victorious,’ he answered, ‘for the Lord will give it into the king’s hand.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to him, ‘How many times must I make you swear to tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the Lord?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Micaiah answered, ‘I saw all Israel scattered on the hills like sheep without a shepherd, and the Lord said, “These people have no master. Let each one go home in peace.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, ‘Didn’t I tell you that he never prophesies anything good about me, but only bad?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah continued, ‘Therefore hear the word of the Lord: I saw the Lord sitting on his throne with all the multitudes of heaven standing round him on his right and on his left.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the Lord said, “Who will entice Ahab into attacking Ramoth Gilead and going to his death there?”
‘One suggested this, and another that.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, a spirit came forward, stood before the Lord and said, “I will entice him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘“By what means?” the Lord asked.
‘“I will go out and be a deceiving spirit in the mouths of all his prophets,” he said.
‘“You will succeed in enticing him,” said the Lord. “Go and do it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘So now the Lord has put a deceiving spirit in the mouths of all these prophets of yours. The Lord has decreed disaster for you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zedekiah son of Kenaanah went up and slapped Micaiah in the face. ‘Which way did the spirit from the Lord go when he went from me to speak to you?’ he asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah replied, ‘You will find out on the day you go to hide in an inner room.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel then ordered, ‘Take Micaiah and send him back to Amon the ruler of the city and to Joash the king’s son
speaker: Narrator

text: and say, “This is what the king says: put this fellow in prison and give him nothing but bread and water until I return safely.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah declared, ‘If you ever return safely, the Lord has not spoken through me.’ Then he added, ‘Mark my words, all you people!’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah went up to Ramoth Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, ‘I will enter the battle in disguise, but you wear your royal robes.’ So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king of Aram had ordered his thirty-two chariot commanders, ‘Do not fight with anyone, small or great, except the king of Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they thought, ‘Surely this is the king of Israel.’ So they turned to attack him, but when Jehoshaphat cried out,
speaker: Narrator

text: the chariot commanders saw that he was not the king of Israel and stopped pursuing him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But someone drew his bow at random and hit the king of Israel between the sections of his armour. The king told his chariot driver, ‘Wheel around and get me out of the fighting. I’ve been wounded.’
speaker: Narrator

text: All day long the battle raged, and the king was propped up in his chariot facing the Arameans. The blood from his wound ran onto the floor of the chariot, and that evening he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the sun was setting, a cry spread through the army: ‘Every man to his town. Every man to his land!’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king died and was brought to Samaria, and they buried him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They washed the chariot at a pool in Samaria (where the prostitutes bathed), and the dogs licked up his blood, as the word of the Lord had declared.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the other events of Ahab’s reign, including all he did, the palace he built and adorned with ivory, and the cities he fortified, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab rested with his ancestors. And Ahaziah his son succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat son of Asa became king of Judah in the fourth year of Ahab king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat was thirty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for twenty-five years. His mother’s name was Azubah daughter of Shilhi.
speaker: Narrator

text: In everything he followed the ways of his father Asa and did not stray from them; he did what was right in the eyes of the Lord. The high places, however, were not removed, and the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat was also at peace with the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the other events of Jehoshaphat’s reign, the things he achieved and his military exploits, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: He rid the land of the rest of the male-shrine prostitutes who remained there even after the reign of his father Asa.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was then no king in Edom; a provincial governor ruled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jehoshaphat built a fleet of trading ships to go to Ophir for gold, but they never set sail – they were wrecked at Ezion Geber.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Ahaziah son of Ahab said to Jehoshaphat, ‘Let my men sail with yours,’ but Jehoshaphat refused.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoshaphat rested with his ancestors and was buried with them in the city of David his father. And Jehoram his son succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah son of Ahab became king of Israel in Samaria in the seventeenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah, and he reigned over Israel for two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord, because he followed the ways of his father and mother and of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He served and worshipped Baal and aroused the anger of the Lord, the God of Israel, just as his father had done.
speaker: Narrator
